author: _emptymind
content: I actually quite like this idea. So it goes like this at withdrawal: 1) You initiate withdrawal 2) The withdrawal process waits x number of blocks to ensure there are no additional conflicting withdrawal requests to different addresses 3) At the end of the period if there is only one requested withdrawal address the validator is exited and funds transferred. If not the validator continues and keys are locked until a court makes a decision. The interesting bit is we build a smart contract for legal purposes and that is the only way to unlock the keys. The only difficulty then becomes defining who "the courts" are. But if that challenge could be overcome then the problem is mostly solved. I mean, what are the chances your attacker would even show up in court?

author: _emptymind
content: The good thing about this is it solves multiple issues. If you never had your keys compromised you are unaffected. If you did but you didn't realise then when the attacker tries to exit you send your own exit request to block it. If you try to exit to the wrong address by mistake you have a window to try again and then explain in court what happened. And devs never need to get involved in legal issues of ownership best left to the courts, who in turn would not have any mechanism to get involved unless a conflict exists.

author: _emptymind
content: Personally I think that any withdrawal mechanism that is designed should incorporate a grace period to listen for conflicting withdrawal requests IN CASE it is decided to do something about it. Even if it is only to identify how widespread the issue is. From a logical point of view I hate the idea that the fastest to get the message out should get the funds.

author: _emptymind
content: "Compromised keys" is a condition that can be tested for, even if we don't want to do anything about it.
